patterns: What might cause severe menstrual cramps?
What can cause severe menstrual cramps?
responses: Conditions such as endometriosis or uterine fibroids can cause severe menstrual cramps.

Menstrual cramps can be caused by:Endometriosis. Tissue that acts similar to the lining of the uterus grows outside of the uterus, most commonly on fallopian tubes, ovaries or the tissue lining your pelvis
Uterine fibroids. These noncancerous growths in the wall of the uterus can cause pain
Adenomyosis. The tissue that lines your uterus begins to grow into the muscular walls of the uterus
Pelvic inflammatory disease. This infection of the female reproductive organs is usually caused by sexually transmitted bacteria
Cervical stenosis. In some women, the opening of the cervix is small enough to impede menstrual flow, causing a painful increase of pressure within the uteru

Period pain is pain that occurs just before or during a menstrual period.Every person’s experience of period pain is different, but it can cause: /n a cramping sensation in the abdomen /n burning pain in the abdomen pain that may feel like trapped gas pain that radiates to the back, hips, or legs.Some peopleTrusted Source also experience digestive symptoms alongside period pain, such as: /n bloating /n diarrhea /n constipation /n nausea /n vomiting
Some peopleTrusted Source also experience digestive symptoms alongside period pain, such as: /n bloating /n diarrhea /n constipation /n nausea /n vomiting

Period pain is pain that occurs just before or during a menstrual period.Every person’s experience of period pain is different, but it can cause: /n a cramping sensation in the abdomen /n burning pain in the abdomen pain that may feel like trapped gas pain that radiates to the back, hips, or legs.
Other symptoms associated with dysmenorrhea include irritability and headaches. Period pain and cramping can vary from mild to intense

patterns: how may types of period pain
what are the types of period pain
responses: There are two types of period pain: primary and secondary /n please type primary or secondary
Primary dysmenorrhea occurs as a result of menstruation alone. This means another condition does not cause it. /n As a period begins, the body releases prostaglandins.
This triggers contractions in the uterus, prompting the womb lining to shed.
People with primary dysmenorrhea also often experience longer, heavier periods

/n ertain risk factors may contribute to the condition, including: /n smokin /n stress /n anxiety or depression /n having excess weight /n trying to lose weight /n beginning periods at an early age /n never having been pregnant /n a family history of painful periods
Secondary dysmenorrhea occurs as a result of another medical condition. Examples of conditions that can cause secondary dysmenorrhea.

intents.tag: How to get rid of period pain
responses: There are a number of approaches people can try to reduce period pain. Coping strategies can reduce current pain, while others may help reduce the likelihood of dysmenorrhea overall. /n Coping with period pain /n Some strategies that may help relieve period pain when it occurs include: /n nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) such as ibuprofen /n heat therapy, such as a heating pad, hot water bottle, or warm bath /n transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS), which people can use at home, work, or school via portable TENS machines /n having an orgasm, either alone or with a partner /n gentle exercise /n acupuncture or acupressure

intents.tag: What to know about menstrual cramps
patterns: What to know about menstrual cramps
responses: Menstrual cramps are painful sensations that affect many people before and during a menstrual period

The pain, also known as dysmenorrhea or period pain, ranges from dull and bothersome to severe and extreme. Menstrual cramps tend to begin after ovulation, when the ovaries release an egg that travels down the fallopian tube
Pain can affect the lower abdomen and lower back. In about 10%Trusted Source of people who menstruate, the discomfort is severe enough to affect their daily life for 1–3 days each month.

Pain that only occurs with menstruation is known as primary dysmenorrhea. Secondary dysmenorrhea is period pain that stems from a medical problem, such as endometriosis, uterine fibroids, or pelvic inflammatory disease

patterns: What are the symptoms of menstruation
what are the symptoms of period
responses: Menstrual cramps usually refer to a dull, throbbing, cramping pain in the lower abdomen, just above the pelvic bone. The pain can also spread to the lower back and thighs./n The pain may be accompanied by nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and bloating. Some women also experience headaches, dizziness, and fatigue./n The pain /n may be mild or severe, and it may last for a few hours or several days. /n The pain may be accompanied by nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and bloating. /n Some women also experience headaches, dizziness, and fatigue. /nThe pain may be mild or severe, and it may last for a few hours or several days.

can also try certain lifestyle measures to reduce cramping. for treatment you can prefer home remedies & herbal remedies /n if you want to know more about home remedies & herbal remedies please type home remedies or herbal remedies

Some natural remediesTrusted Source that may provide relief are: /n applying a heat pad to the lower abdomen /n practicing relaxation and mindfulness techniques /n engaging in physical exercise, such as jogging or yoga /n taking a warm bath or shower /n having a massage /n using transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS)

Various herbal teas and other herbal remedies may help manage symptoms, although research has not yet proven that they can help /n Chamomile tea /n Chinese herbal medicines /n Pine bark /n Fennel /n Aromatherapy /n Ginger

patterns: What is the best tea for menstrual cramps?
responses: There is insufficient evidence to conclude that any specific herbal tea can treat menstrual cramps. However, limited research suggests that consuming ginger and green teaTrusted Source may help treat symptoms.

patterns: Can juices help with period cramps?
Can juices help with period cramps
responses: Eating more fruits and vegetables may help reduceTrusted Source a person’s menstrual cramps. However, there is insufficient evidence to determine whether drinking specific juices will help.

patterns: Can vitamin D help with period cramps?
vitamin D help with period cramps
vitamin D help with period pain
vitamin D help with menstrual cramps
responses: There is insufficient evidence to determine whether vitamin D can help treat menstrual cramps. However, vitamin D may help reduceTrusted Source the risk of developing chronic pain conditions, such as fibromyalgia.

intents.tag: What can make period cramps worse?
patterns: What can make period cramps worse?
What can make period pain worse?
What can make menstrual cramps worse?
responses: Several factors and underlying conditions may increase a person’s risk of experiencing severe menstrual cramps, including: /n a family history of severe cramps /n being under 20 years of age /n having obesity /n endometriosi .n fibroids /n pelvic inflammatory disease /n adenomyosis /n low intake of omega-3 /n smoking /n stress

symptoms that should not be ignored
responses: Heavy bleeding /n Spotting /n Skipped periods /n Breast tenderness /n Diarrhea /n Clotting /n Unusual consistency /n Cramps /n Migraine /n Irregular periods /n Significant mood changes /n Period not stopping

If any severe symptom occurs during a period, or if a period has any unusual features, it is a good idea to see a doctor./n A person should also see a healthcare provider about any of the followingTrusted Source: /n unusual vaginal discharge /n a burning sensation while urinating /n a fever /n severe pain at any time
